titleStmt.title: A hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm for a flow shop scheduling problem with bi-objectives: Weighted mean completion time and weighted mean tardiness

analytic.title: A hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm for a flow shop scheduling problem with bi-objectives: Weighted mean completion time and weighted mean tardiness

biblStruct.note: Received 13 July 2006; received in revised form 31 May 2007; accepted 6 June 2007

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper investigates a novel multi-objective model for a no-wait flow shop scheduling problem that minimizes both the weighted mean completion time ðC w Þ and weighted mean tardiness ðT w Þ. Obtaining an optimal solution for this type of complex, large-sized problem in reasonable computational time by using traditional approaches and optimization tools is extremely difficult. This paper presents a new hybrid multi-objective algorithm based on the features of a biological immune system (IS) and bacterial optimization (BO) to find Pareto optimal solutions for the given problem. To validate the performance of the proposed hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm (HMOIA) in terms of solution quality and diversity level, various test problems are examined. Further, the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, based on various metrics, is compared against five prominent multi-objective evolutionary algorithms: PS-NC GA, NSGA-II, SPEA-II, MOIA, and MISA. Our computational results suggest that our proposed HMOIA outperforms the five foregoing algorithms, especially for large-sized problems.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The processing of a given number of jobs (commodities) on a specified number of machines (facilities), referred to elsewhere in the literature as scheduling, dispatching, sequencing, or combinations, continues to be an operational problem in manufacturing environments [22]. 0020-0255/$ -see front matter Ó 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. doi:10.1016/j.ins.2007.06. 001 In most manufacturing environments, a set of processes is sequentially performed in several stages to complete a job. Such a system is referred to as the flow shop environment, and belongs to a class of scheduling problems [3]. In a flow shop problem, we consider n different jobs that are to be processed on m machines in the same order so that the performance measures are optimized. Common measures are the makespan, earliness, tardiness, mean completion time, work-in-process penalty, number of tardy jobs, and idle time. It is suggested in the review of recent literature that flow shop scheduling problems have been among the most prevalent problems in the area of scheduling. Numerous papers have investigated this issue [35]. A comprehensive review of flow shop scheduling problems over the last 50 years is provided by Gupta and Stafford [22].

In some practical applications, such as the metal, plastic, chemical and food industries, jobs must be processed on m machines continuously; therefore, intermediate storage does not exist between successive machines. This type of flow shop scheduling problem addressed in the literature is referred to as a no-wait flow shop problem. Hall and Sriskandarajah [23] provided a useful survey for scheduling problems with blocking and no-wait in process. Espinouse et al. [17] considered a two-machine no-wait flow shop scheduling problem by minimizing the makespan with limited machine availability. Bertolissi [5] proposed a heuristic algorithm for a no-wait flow shop scheduling problem, in which the total flow time was considered as the primary criterion. Hong and Wang [24] considered a fuzzy approach for a generalized flow shop scheduling problem. They used triangular membership functions for a flexible flow shop problem with two machining centers examining processing-time uncertainties in order to make scheduling more suitable for real applications. Fink and Vob [18] considered the application of different metaheuristics such as neighborhood search, simulated annealing and Tabu search to solve a continuous flow shop problem with a practical approach. They further examined the trade-offs between the running time and the solution quality as well as the knowledge and effort needed to implement and calibrate their proposed algorithm. Thornton and Hunsucker [47] developed a new heuristic that minimizes the makespan in a flow shop scheduling problem with multiple processors and no intermediate storage.

Bouquard et al. [7] provided complexity classification for various versions of a two-machine permutation flow shop scheduling problem to minimize the makespan, in which some jobs processed with no-wait in process. Spieksma and Woeginger [43] considered a no-wait flow shop paradox. They showed that increasing the speed of some machines in a no-wait flow shop instance may worsen the optimal makespan. Grabowski and Pempera [20] developed and compared different local search algorithms for a no-wait flow shop problem with the makespan criterion. Kumar et al. [32] proposed a Psycho-Clonal algorithm-based approach to solve a nowait flow shop scheduling problem with the total flow times as the main criterion. Wang [49] considered general, no-wait, and no-idle flow shop scheduling problems with deteriorating jobs. Oulamara [36] investigated a task-scheduling problem in a no-wait flow shop with two batching machines by minimizing makespan as an objective. Su and Lee [44] studied a two-machine flow shop no-wait scheduling problem with a single server, in which the performance measure was the total completion time. They provided both heuristic and branch-andbound (B/B) algorithms to tackle the given problem. Kalczynski and Kamburowski [28] dealt with minimizing the makespan in m-machine no-wait and no-idle permutation flow shops. Pan et al. [37] developed and successfully applied a discrete particle swarm optimization algorithm to solve a no-wait flow shop scheduling problem with bi-criteria of the makespan and the total flow times.

Some researchers have addressed multi-objective flow shop scheduling problems. Murata et al. [35] considered a flow shop scheduling problem in two variants; first, with the two objectives of the makespan and total tardiness penalties, and second, with the three objectives of the makespan, total tardiness penalties, and total flow times. To do so, they proposed a multi-objective genetic algorithm. Ponnambalam et al. [39] proposed a multi-objective TSP-GA algorithm for a flow shop scheduling problem, in which they used the weighted sum of multiple objectives, i.e., minimizing makespan, mean flow times, and machine idle times. Toktas et al. [48] considered a two-machine flow shop scheduling problem to minimize the makespan and maximum earliness. Ravindran et al. [41] proposed three heuristic algorithms to solve a bi-objective flow shop scheduling problem, in which makespan and total flow times are considered. Rahimi-Vahed and Mirghorbani [40] devised a multiobjective particle swarm algorithm for a bi-criteria flow shop scheduling problem to minimize the weighted mean completion time and weighted mean tardiness. They empirically showed that their method outperforms a multi-objective genetic algorithm on a set of representative problems. Tavakkoli-Moghaddam et al. [46] proposed a multi-objective immune algorithm for a flow shop scheduling problem and compared this algorithm with a conventional multi-objective genetic algorithm, i.e., SPEA-II.

In this paper, we address a multi-objective no-wait flow shop scheduling problem, in which weighted mean completion time and weighted mean tardiness must be optimized simultaneously. To tackle this problem, a hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm (HMOIA) is proposed to search for the locally Pareto-optimal frontier. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Basic definitions of the multi-objective optimization are presented in Sections 2 and 3 gives the problem definition, and in Section 4, background of the immune algorithm approach is described and the proposed algorithm is outlined. The computational results and numerical comparisons are reported in Section 5, and the conclusions are presented in Section 6.

div.head: Multi-objective optimization
div.p: Many real-world problems involve simultaneous optimization of several objective functions. In general, these functions often compete and conflict with themselves. Multi-objective optimization with such conflicting objective functions provides a set of optimal solutions (called Pareto-optimal), rather than one optimal solution. This set includes the solutions that no other solution is better than with respect to all objective functions. Without loss of generality, let us consider a typical multi-objective minimization problem with p decision variables and q objectives (q > 1): Min y ¼ f ðxÞ ¼ ðf 1 ðxÞ; f 2 ðxÞ; . . . ; f q ðxÞÞ; ð1Þ
where, x 2 R p , and y 2 R q .
Definition 2.1. Solution a is said to dominate solution b if and only if:
ð1Þ f i ðaÞ 6 f i ðbÞ 8i 2 f1; 2; . . . ; qg; ð2Þ ð2Þ f i ðaÞ < f i ðbÞ 9i 2 f1; 2; . . . ; qg:
Solutions that dominate the other solutions but do not dominate themselves are called non-dominated solutions.
Definition 2.2. Vector a is a globally Pareto-optimal solution if vector b does not exist such that b dominates a.

The set of all Pareto-optimal solutions is also called the Pareto-optimal set, or the efficient set. The corresponding images of the Pareto-optimal set in the objective space are called the Pareto-optimal frontier.

The development of various methodologies to solve multi-objective problems has been an on-going effort by researchers. There are various methods for solving multi-objective optimization problems [10]. These methods can be classified into five categories as follows: (1) scalar methods, (2) interactive methods, (3) fuzzy methods, (4) metaheuristic methods, and (5) decision aid methods. Among these methods, metaheuristic methods seem to be practically suited for solving multi-objective optimization problems. Different approaches appear in the literature, for example, Vector Evaluated Genetic Algorithm [42], Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithm (MOGA) [19], Niched Pareto Genetic Algorithm (NPGA) [25], Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm (NSGA and NSGA-II) ( [14,15]), Pareto Stratum-Niche Cubicle Genetic Algorithm (PS-NC GA) [26], Multiple Objective Genetic Local Search (MOGLS) [27], Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm (SPEA and SPEA2) ( [55,56]), Micro-Genetic Algorithm [9], Pareto Archive Evolution Strategy (PAES) [31], Multi-Objective Tabu Search (MOTS) [38], and Multi-Objective Scatter Search (MOSS) [4].

div.head: No-wait flow shop scheduling problem
div.p: A flow shop scheduling problem concerns a set of n jobs, I = {1, 2, . . ., n}, that must be processed on a set of m machines, J = {1, 2, . . ., m}, with the same processing order for jobs. Job i 2 I consists of a sequence of m operations O i1 , O i2 , . . ., O im ; operation O ij denotes the processing of job i on machine j during uninterrupted processing time p ij . Each schedule of jobs can be represented by permutation u = (u(1), . . ., u(n)) on set I.
Given job permutation u, completion time C u(i)j of job u(i) on machine j can be computed by using the following recursive formula:
div.formula: C uðiÞj ¼ C uðiÀ1Þ;1 þ X j l¼1 P uðiÞl þ EðuðiÞÞ i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; n j ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; m;ð4Þ
div.p: where,
div.formula: EðuðiÞÞ ¼ max 0; max C uðiÀ1Þ;j À C uðiÀ1Þ;1 þ X jÀ1 l¼1 P uðiÞl ! ! " # j ¼ 2; . . . ; m;ð5Þ
uð0Þ ¼ 0; C 0j ¼ 0 j ¼ 1; . . . ; m:ð6Þ
div.p: In certain practical applications with continuous job processing such as in plastic, chemical or food industries, the system does not lend itself to intermediate storage among the machines. This particular form of the flow shop scheduling problem has been referred to as a no-wait flow shop problem, in which each job must be processed from start to finish without any interruption. In other words, to fulfill the no-wait restrictions, the completion time of operation O ij must be equal to the starting time of operation

It is worth noting that a no-wait flow shop scheduling problem with availability constraints is NP-hard in the strong sense [20]. This means that no pseudo-polynomial time algorithm can optimally solve the bi-criteria no-wait flow shop scheduling problem considered in this paper.

div.head: Minimizing the weighted mean completion time
div.p: In this paper, the first objective minimizes the weighted mean completion time i:e:; C w ¼ 1
div.formula: W P i w i C i À Á
div.p: , in which C i is the completion time for job i, w i is the assigned weight to job i, and W ¼ P i w i . This problem is denoted as F jnwtj 1 W P i w i C i .

div.head: Minimizing the weighted mean tardiness
div.p: The second objective minimizes the weighted mean tardiness i:e:; T w ¼ 1
div.formula: W P i w i T i À Á
div.p: , in which w i is the weight assigned to job i, T i = max{0, C i À d i } is the tardiness of job i, and d i indicates the due date of job i. This problem is denoted as F jnwtj 1 W P i w i T i .

div.head: Artificial immune systems
div.p: The biological immune system is a robust, complex, and adaptive system that defends the body from foreign pathogens. It is able to categorize all cells (or molecules) within the body as self-cells or non-self cells. Depending on the type of pathogen and the way it inters the body, the immune system uses different response mechanisms to either neutralize the pathogenic effect or destroy the infected cells [34]. The immune defense mechanism is either non-specific (innate) or specific (acquired) [30]. The former is obtained through evolution from generation to generation and the latter is learned through its own encounters with antigens. The clonal selection and affinity maturation principles are used to explain how the immune system reacts to pathogens and how it improves its capability of recognizing and eliminating them [1]. The immune system mostly consists of the immune cells. The most common type of immune cells is lymphocytes (i.e., B-cells and T-cells). Both cells have receptor molecules on their surfaces that are able to recognize disease-causing pathogens (antigens). The B-cell receptor molecule is also called an antibody [16]. Clonal selection states that by pathogen invasion, a number of immune cells (lymphocytes) that recognize these pathogens will proliferate; some of them will become effecter cells (plasma cells), while others will be maintained as memory cells. The effecter cells secrete antibodies in large numbers, and the memory cells have long life spans and can therefore act faster and more effectively in future exposures to the same or a similar pathogen [53]. During cellular reproduction, the cells suffer somatic mutations at high rates, and are also subjected to a selective force; the cells with higher affinity to the invading pathogen differentiate into memory cells. Generally, cells with low affinity receptors mutate at a higher rate, whereas cells with high affinity receptors will have a lower mutation rate [30]. This whole process of somatic mutation plus selection is known as affinity maturation [53].

A novel computational intelligence technique inspired by immunology has emerged, known as artificial immune systems (AISs), in which several concepts from immunology have been extracted and applied to the solution of real-world science and engineering problems [34].

div.head: Previous work in artificial immune systems
div.p: Recently, artificial immune systems have attracted special attention in various applications. Dasgupta and Forrest [11] considered using a negative selection algorithm for tool breakage detection in milling operations. Zak [52] addressed the physical model of immune-inspired computing and introduced stochastic models that mimic the phenomenology of basic functions of immune systems such as self and non-self discrimination, selfrepair, predator-prey pursuit, and reproduction. De Castro and Von Zuben [12,13] used the clonal selection principle to perform machine learning and pattern recognition tasks, and to solve optimization problems. Luh et al. [33] proposed an immune-based algorithm to find Pareto optimal solutions for multi-objective optimization problems. Coello and Cortes [8] applied the clonal selection principle to solve multi-objective optimization problems. Guimaraes et al. [21] addressed a mixed H 2 /H 1 control design with optimization algorithms inspired by the immune system. Zhang [54] developed a dynamic immune optimization algorithm for constrained non-linear multi-objective optimization problems over continuous domains. The proposed algorithm is based on the concept of Pareto optimality and simple interactive metaphors between antibody population and multiple antigens as well as ideas of T-cell regulation. Yuan and Chu [51] used an immune algorithm to optimize the parameters in support vector machines problems.

Khilwani et al. [29] designed a clonal algorithm to solve various numerical and combinatorial real-world optimization problems. They also used an artificial immune algorithm to tackle scheduling problems. Alisantoso et al. [2] considered a flexible PCB flow shop scheduling problem by using an immune algorithm. Khoo and Situmdrang [30] dealt with the design of an assembly system for modular products by using an approach based on the principles of natural immune systems. Engin and Doyen [16] applied clonal selection principles and an affinity maturation mechanism to a hybrid flow shop scheduling problem. Kumar et al. [32] used an artificial immune system to tackle a continuous flow shop problem with total flow times as the principal criterion. Zandieh et al. [53] used an immune algorithm to solve hybrid flow shop scheduling problems with sequence-dependent setup times.

div.head: The proposed hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm (HMOIA)
div.p: The algorithm proposed in this paper is based on the clonal selection principle, which recognizes that only the highest affinity antibodies will proliferate. The criterion distinguishing between antigens and antibodies is Pareto dominance. In other words, non-dominated solutions are the antigens and dominated solutions are the antibodies. The HMOIA implementation is described in the following sections.

div.head: General scheme of HMOIA
div.p: The pseudo-code of HMOIA is illustrated in Fig. 1.

div.head: Antibody representation
div.p: A typical representation in a scheduling problem is the job-to-position representation, in which a single-row array whose size is equal to the number of jobs is created. The first element of the array denotes the first job in a sequence; the second element of the array denotes the second job, and so on (see Fig. 2). The inherent characteristics of particle swarm optimization (PSO) suggest difficulties in applying this type of representation; the operators applied on real values often need to be redefined in order to make them applicable to a permutation of jobs. Although several researchers have successfully defined new operators, others have utilized real-coded representation with their respective decoding to obtain a permutation [45,40].

In this study, real-coded representation is used along with job-to-position representation whenever immune algorithm operators are to be applied to a solution. In a problem with n jobs, a real-coded representation is an array containing n real values. These values indicate a antibody's position in each dimension of the n-dimensional space they move into. However, an upper bound for these values, referred to as X max , places a limit on the maximum distance each solution is permitted to travel in each dimension. In this paper, X max is set to 4. Consequently, a strategy (which is described later in this section) to convert the two representation types together when needed is necessary.

Fig. 2 illustrates a sample of the job-to-position representation. To construct the continuous version of this representation, we first need to generate 7 (the number of jobs to be produced) random numbers between [0, x max ] = [0, 4]. These numbers are then sorted, and the smallest is assigned to the position that contains the first job, which is job number 1. The next smallest is assigned to a position that contains the second job, which is job number 2, and so on. We can suppose that the numbers shown in Table 1 are the random numbers obtained.

To build the continuous representation, we assign 0.46 to job number 1, 1.54 to job number 2, 1.77 to job number 3 and so on. Fig. 3 shows the associated representation. To illustrate how the job-to-position representation is obtained from the representation shown in Fig. 3, we need to schedule the first job in the place of the first smallest values of the continuous representation, the second job in the place of the next smallest values, and so on.

div.head: Antibody initialization
div.p: Most evolutionary algorithms use a random procedure to generate an initial set of solutions. However, since the output results are strongly sensitive to the initial set, we propose a new Elite Tabu Search (ETS) mechanism to construct this set of solutions. The main purpose of applying this metaheuristic method is to build a set of potentially diverse and high quality antibodies in the job-to-position representation form. Before describing the elements of the proposed Tabu search, we need to define the notion of the ''Ideal Point''. The ideal point for a multi-objective problem is a virtual point whose coordinates are obtained by separately optimizing each objective function with the same Pareto.

Determining the ideal point requires separately optimizing each of the objective functions of the problem. However, optimizing even a single objective non-linear problem is a difficult task. To overcome this obstacle, the problem is first linearized. Then, each of the objective functions is solved to optimality with available optimization software packages, such as Lingo 8. Another problem in the process of finding the ideal point, even after linearization, is the NP-hardness of the problems, which prohibits finding the global optimum (even a strong local optimum) in a reasonable time. As such, an approximation of the Ideal Point is used instead. The approximation involves interrupting the optimization software (Lingo 8) f seconds after the first feasible solution is found. The best solution found in this way is considered as the corresponding coordinate of the ideal point. The value of f is determined after running various test problems.

div.head: ETS implementation.
div.p: The desired size of the antibody repertoire, which is shown by N, remains constant during the optimization process. To construct N diverse and good antibodies, the proposed Elite Tabu Search (ETS) must be conducted a • N times, where a is an integer greater than or equal to 1. The Tabu Search starts from a predetermined point, called the Starting Point, which can be set to the sequence of either of the two values obtained for coordinates of the ideal point. In our paper, the string of objective function (1) is considered as the starting point. Then, the current solution is saved in a virtual list and is replaced by a desired solution in its neighborhood that meets the acceptance criterion. This process continues until the pre-specified termination criterion is met. The detailed description of the proposed Tabu search is given in the next section.

4.3.3.1.1. Move description. The proposed move procedure, which is used to generate a neighborhood subset l, is based on an implementation of what is known in the GA literature as the inversion operator. Inversion is an array operator that first chooses two random cut points in an antibody. The elements between the cut points are then reversed. An example of the inversion operator is presented below.

Before inversion: 2 1 3 j 4 5 6 7 j 9 8. After inversion: 2 1 3 j 7 6 5 4 j 9 8. 4.3.3.1.2. Tabu list. The move mechanism uses the intelligent Tabu Search strategy, whose principle is to avoid returning to the solution recently visited by using an adaptive memory called Tabu List. The proposed Tabu list is attributive and consists of a list of pairs of integers (i, j), where i,j 2 {1,. . .,n}. It means that it is forbidden to inverse the subsequence of jobs between the position i and the position j, if the pair (i, j) exists in the Tabu List. The Tabu List size, shown as w, is pre-determined and has a sufficiently large value. To diversify the search, long-term memory is employed and the Tabu Tenure (Tmax) is set to infinity. In addition, decencybased and frequency-based memories are used.

div.head: Search direction.
div.p: To simultaneously maintain intensification and diversification, we introduce a new function based on a Goal Programming method. This function can be shown as follows:
div.formula: f ¼ X k i¼1 jf i À F i j w i ;ð7Þ
div.p: where, f i is the ith objective function value of the solution, F i is the ith coordinate value of the ideal point, and w i is the weight of the ith objective function. The motivation for using this metric is that it provides a solution as close as possible to the true Pareto front for a given set of weights w if it minimizes the value of f. The main difference between the proposed function and existing functions is that it facilitates working with a set of solutions that is not necessarily convex. This advantage makes the proposed ETS very convenient to be implemented in every optimization problem with every search space pattern. Another advantage is achieved by generating w i randomly. According to this approach, the proposed ETS can search the solution space in various directions, so that high diversification is maintained.
To explain the acceptance criteria of a new solution, the variable g is defined as follows:
div.formula: g ¼ f B À f A ;ð8Þ
div.p: where A is the current solution and B is generated from A by a recent move. Therefore, the acceptance criteria can be defined as:
1. If g 6 0 and the move is not Tabu, solution A is replaced by B.
2. If g 6 0 but the move is Tabu, the aspiration strategy is used and solution A is replaced by B.
3. If g > 0 and the move is not Tabu, solution A is replaced by B when solution B is not dominated by solution A. 4. If g > 0 and the move is Tabu, solution A does not change.

4.3.3.1.4. Stopping criteria. We can use many stopping criteria depending on the nature of the problem being investigated. The most common criterion employed in this paper is the maximum number of iterations. In other words, the proposed ETS is iterated for a • Ntimes. After completing the ETS iterations, a • N solutions will be selected from among the whole set of visited solutions by ETS to be as close to the Pareto front as possible. To prepare the initial set for the HMOIA algorithm, we select those N solutions with the shortest distance to the dynamic ideal point.

div.head: Adaptive Pareto archive set
div.p: In many investigations, a Pareto archive set is provided to explicitly maintain a limited number of nondominated solutions. This approach is incorporated to prevent losing certain portions of the current non-dominated front during the optimization process. This archive is iteratively updated to get closer to the correct Pareto-optimal front. When a new non-dominated solution is found, it enters the archive set if the archive set is not full; otherwise, it is ignored. When a new solution enters the archive set, any solution in the archive dominated by this solution is removed from the set.

Once the maximum archive size is exceeded, removing a non-dominated solution may destroy the characteristics of the trade-off front. There are many different and efficient methods to deal with the updating procedure when the archive size is exceeded. The most widely adopted techniques are clustering and k-nearest neighbor methods; however, most of these algorithms do not preclude the problem of temporary deteriorating the solution, and delaying the convergence to the Pareto set.
In this study, we propose an adaptive Pareto archive set updating procedure that attempts to prevent losing new non-dominated solutions when the Pareto archive has reached its maximum size.

The archive size, which is shown by Arch_size, is a pre-specified value and must be set at the beginning of the algorithm. When a new non-dominated solution is found, one of the two following possibilities may occur.

1. The number of solutions in the archive set is less than Arch_size, thus this solution joins the archive set. 2. The number of solutions in the archive set is equal to (or greater than) Arch_size, thus the new solution will be added if its distance to the nearest non-dominated solution in the archive is greater-than-or-equal-to the ''Duplication Area'' of that nearest non-dominated solution in the archive. Consequently, the size of the Pareto archive increases.

The duplication area of a non-dominated solution in the Pareto archive is defined as a bowl around the solution, with radius k. This area is used as a measure of dissimilarity in order to find diverse non-dominated solutions. The distance between the new non-dominated solution and the nearest non-dominated solution in the archive is measured based on the Euclidean distance. In other words, if the new non-dominated solution is not located in the duplication area of its nearest non-dominated solution, it is considered as a dissimilar solution and added to the Pareto archive set.

The main advantage of this procedure is that it allows saving dissimilar non-dominated solutions without losing any existing non-dominated solutions in the archive. It must be noted that, the Pareto archive is updated at the end of each iteration of the proposed algorithm.

div.head: Cloning
div.p: In clonal selection, only the highest affinity antibodies will be selected to go into the pool. In our proposed approach, antibodies gain membership to the pool according to their quality or diversity. In other words, the pool is a subset of both diverse and high quality antibodies that consists of an approximation of the Pareto-optimal set.

The construction of the pool starts with the selection of all non-repeated, non-dominated antibodies from the Pareto archive set. If the number of such non-dominated antibodies is smaller than the required pool size, the remaining antibodies are selected from among the dominated antibodies. For this purpose, the dominated antibodies are divided into various fronts, and the required numbers of antibodies are selected with the selection mechanism shown in Fig. 4.

In this study, the hamming distance is used as a measure to diversify the solution space. This measure is the number of positions in two strings of equal length for which the corresponding elements are different. It allows measuring the number of substitutions required to change one into another.

div.head: Hyper mutation
div.p: The high affinity antibodies selected in the previous step are submitted to the process of hyper mutation. This process consists of two phases that are implemented in a sequential manner, as follows.

4.3.6.1. Antibodies combination. The combination method that we implemented is based on linear combination. Each time the combination procedure is used, a pre-specified number of clones (b) are selected randomly and linearly combined to produce a new antibody. Let b be 3 and x i , x j and x k be the selected antibodies being combined, then the new antibody x l is obtained with the following line search: It is important to note that the selected clones must be in their continuous representations and that w i , i = 1, 2, 3 are generated at random. 4.3.6.2. Antibodies improvement. Each of the antibodies obtained from the previous step goes through to the improvement method. This method aims to enhance the quality of these solutions.
div.formula: x l ¼ w 1 x i þ w 2 x j þ w 3 x k ; X 3 i¼1 w i ¼ 1:
div.p: Two operators of the bacterial method, known as bacterial mutation and gene transfer, are applied consecutively when the improvement method is implemented. Bacterial optimization was first introduced by Botzheim and Koczy [6] and is inspired by the microbial evolution phenomenon. The bacterial mutation operation tries to optimize a single solution, while gene transfer provides the opportunity for the solutions in the population to transfer information by recombination. These operators are described in the next section.

4.3.6.2.1. Bacterial mutation. Bacterial mutation starts by creating a number of copies of the solution. These copies then go through the mutation operator. Next, all the copies and the original solution are evaluated, and only the best of these solutions survive. The details of this operator are described below.

1. N clones copies of the solution are generated so that there are (N clones + 1) identical solutions available. 2. The inversion operator is applied to each of the N clones copies. 3. The solution surviving the mutation is the non-dominated solution among the mutated solutions and the original one with the highest crowding distance. All other solutions are discarded. 4. The above procedure is repeated for all of the solutions in the pool. 4.3.6.2.2. Gene transfer. Another operation of bacterial optimization is gene transfer, which suggests that antibodies are allowed to transfer information by recombination. For this purpose, the pool is first divided into two dichotomies of superior and inferior antibodies. Then, two antibodies from each of the dichotomies are randomly selected, and the inferior solution is worked on to improve it towards the superior solution. This operator functions through the following steps.

1. The pool is divided into two groups: non-dominated and dominated antibodies. 2. One solution is randomly chosen from the non-dominated antibodies and another from the dominated antibodies. 3. In order to improve the dominated antibody towards the non-dominated antibody, each gene of the dominated antibody is checked against its corresponding gene in the non-dominated antibody for equality. If they contain identical values, the dominated antibody maintains the gene; otherwise, the gene becomes empty.

Next, the values missing in the dominated antibody are identified and inserted into the empty genes in a random manner. This operator is illustrated in Fig. 5. In this figure, the values of the 2nd, 4th, and 6th gene are directly copied into the improved solution and the remaining genes are randomly filled with {7, 5, 2, 1}.
Steps 1, 2, and 3 are repeated N inf times, where N inf is the number of ''infections'' per generation.

div.head: Stopping criterion
div.p: The proposed immune algorithm must be repeated a pre-specified number of times.

div.head: Experimental results
div.p: The performance of the proposed HMOIA is compared with five well-known multi-objective evolutionary algorithms, i.e. Pareto stratum-niche cubicle genetic algorithm (PS-NC GA) [26], Non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm-II (NSGA-II) [15], Strength Pareto Evolutionary Algorithm II (SPEA-II) [55], Multi-objective immune algorithm (MOIA) [33], and Multi-objective immune system algorithm (MISA) [8]. These algorithms have been coded in Visual Basic 6 and executed on an AMD Athlon TM XP 64 bit, 3.0 GHz PC, with a Windows XP operating system using 512 MB of RAM.

div.head: Algorithm assumptions
div.p: The experiments are implemented for both small and large-sized problems, with the following assumptions and initial values:
The processing times (P ij ) are integers and are generated from a uniform distribution of U(1, 40); (2) the due dates (d i ) are uniformly distributed in the interval
div.formula: ½P ð1 À T À R 2 Þ; P ð1 À T þ R 2 Þ where P ¼ ðn þ m À 1ÞP
div.p: , with P as the mean total processing time and values of T and R set to 0.2 and 0.6 respectively; (3) the job weights (w i ) are uniformly generated in the interval (1,20); and (4) each experiment is repeated 15 times.
• Hybrid Multi-objective immune algorithm: (1) The value of a is set to 10; (2) the pool size equals the antibody repertoire;
(3) the combination rate is set to 1, (4) the value of b is fixed to 3;and (5) the value of N clones is set to 5.

div.head: Test problems
div.p: The first experiment is carried out on a set of small-sized problems. This experiment contains 16 test problems of different sizes generated according to Table 2.

The proposed HMOIA is applied to these problems and its performance is assessed, using a number of comparison metrics, with that of the multi-objective genetic algorithm. The comparison metrics used are explained in the next section.

div.head: Comparison metrics
div.p: To validate the reliability of the proposed HMOIA, the following five metrics are taken into account.

The number of Pareto solutions. This metric shows the number of Pareto optimal solutions that each algorithm can find. The number of found Pareto solutions corresponding to each algorithm is compared with the total Pareto optimal solutions obtained by the total enumeration algorithm.
Error ratio. This metric allows us to measure the non-convergence of the algorithms towards the Pareto-optimal frontier. The definition of the error ratio is given as follows:
div.formula: E ¼ P N i¼1 e i N ;ð9Þ
div.p: where, N is the number of found Pareto optimal solutions, and e i ¼ 0 if the solution i 2 Pareto-optimal frontier; 1 otherwise:
The closer this metric is to 1, the less the algorithm has converged towards the Pareto-optimal frontier.

div.head: Generational distance.
div.p: This metric measures the distance between the Pareto-optimal frontier and the solution set. The definition of this metric is as follows:
div.formula: G ¼ P N i¼1 d i À Á N ;ð10Þ
div.p: where d i is the Euclidean distance between solution i and the closest solution that belongs to the Pareto-optimal frontier obtained from the total enumeration.

div.head: Spacing metric.
div.p: The spacing metric enables us to measure the uniformity of the point spread within the solution set. The definition of this metric is given below:
div.formula: S ¼ 1 N À 1 Â X N i¼1 d À d i À Á 2 " # 1 2 ;ð11Þ
div.p: where, d is the mean value of all d i .
5.2.2.5. Diversification metric. This metric measures the spread of the solution set. It is defined as:
div.formula: D ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi X N i¼1 max x 0 i À y 0 i k k ð Þ v u u t ;ð12Þ
div.p: where x 0 i À y 0 i is the Euclidean distance between the non-dominated solution x 0 i and the non-dominated solution y 0 i .

div.head: Parameter setting
div.p: To tune the problem, extensive experiments are implemented with different sets of parameters by conducting a comprehensive sensitivity analysis. This strengthens the potential for future improvement of HMOIA by systematically fine-tuning these parameters using statistical tests, as suggested in Xu et al. [50]. After conducting the analysis, the following set was found to be effective in terms of the metrics outlined above.

Hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm's tuned parameters: (1) The size of the antibody repertoire, N, at each iteration is set to 50; (2) the algorithm is terminated after 50 iterations; (3) since each objective function is linear and the lingo software can obtain the best values of the coordinates of the ideal point immediately, the value of n is set to 0; (4) the neighborhood subset size, l, and the Tabu list size, w, are respectively set to 3 and 20, in the ETS; (5) the maximum Pareto archive size, Arch_Size, is fixed at 35; and (6) the value of N inf is fixed at 50. Multi-objective evolutionary algorithms' tuned parameters: (1) The population size is set to 50; (2) the algorithm is terminated after 50 iterations.

div.head: Comparative results
div.p: In this section, the proposed HMOIA is applied to a number of test problems and its performance is compared with multi-objective evolutionary algorithms.

Table 3 shows the average number of Pareto optimal solutions that each algorithm can find. As shown in this table, the proposed HMOIA could achieve a greater number of Pareto optimal solutions in each test problem. The proposed HMOIA has produced more alternative sequences for each point along the locally nondominated frontier, and hence the decision makers have more flexibility in selecting a desirable sequence.

Table 4 presents the average values of error ratios of the algorithms. As illustrated in Table 4, the proposed HMOIA has a better performance than the other algorithms. These data suggest that the HMOIA has a higher rate of convergence towards the Pareto-optimal frontier.

Table 5 shows the average values of generational distances found by each algorithm. In terms of a generational distance metric, the proposed HMOIA achieved Pareto solutions that are closer to the true Paretooptimal frontier in comparison with the benchmark algorithms.

Table 6 presents the average values of the spacing metric obtained by the algorithms. This table also illustrates that the HMOIA provides non-dominated solutions that have lower average values for the spacing metric. Therefore, the non-dominated solutions obtained by the HMOIA are more uniformly distributed in comparison with those obtained by the other algorithms. Table 8 represents the average computational times consumed by each algorithm. These results illustrate that the proposed HMOIA consumes more computational time than the multi-objective evolutionary algorithms. Since the HMOIA can intelligently search more regions of the search space because of the structure of the proposed elitist Tabu search and antibody combination method, its greater computational time is reasonable.

div.head: Test problems
div.p: Another set of experiments is conducted for large-sized problems. For this set, 20 test problems of different sizes are generated according to Table 9.

div.head: Comparison metrics
div.p: Due to the large size of the test problems, it is impossible to find the Pareto-optimal solutions using the naive enumeration algorithm because more appropriate comparison metrics must be used for these problems. In this regard, the following comparison metrics were deemed suitable: (1) the number of non-dominated solutions that each algorithm can find, and (2) the quality metric that is simply measured by putting together the non-dominated solutions found by any two algorithms, say A and B, and evaluating the ratio of the non-dominated solutions discovered by algorithm A to those discovered by algorithm B.

div.head: Parameter setting
div.p: For tuning this category of problem, extensive experiments were implemented with different sets of parameters. The following set was found to be effective in terms of the above-mentioned metrics.

Hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm's tuned parameters: (1) The size of antibody repertoire at each iteration, N, is increased to 200; (2) the algorithm is terminated after 500 iterations; (3) the value of n is set to 300 minutes; (4) the neighborhood subset size, l, and the Tabu list size, w, are respectively fixed at 3 and 40 in the ETS; (5) the maximum Pareto archive size, Arch_Size, is set to 100; and (6) the value of N inf is set to 300. Multi-objective evolutionary algorithms' tuned parameters: (1) The population size is increased to 200; (2) each algorithm is terminated after 500 iterations.

div.head: Comparative results
div.p: Tables 10 and11 represent the average values of the four metrics used and illustrate that the proposed HMOIA shows better performance in both of the problem sets. In other words, HMOIA provides the higher number of diverse locally non-dominated solutions that closer to the true Pareto-optimal frontier. Table 12 depicts the average computational times of the algorithms.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This paper presents a novel, hybrid multi-objective immune algorithm (HMOIA) to solve a no-wait flow shop scheduling problem to minimize the weighted mean completion time and weighted mean tardiness. The validation of the proposed multi-objective immune algorithm necessitated the design of various test problems and evaluated the performance and reliability of the proposed HMOIA in comparison with five multi-objective evolutionary algorithms, namely PS-NC GA, NSGA-II, SPEA-II, MOIA, and MISA, to solve the given problems. Some useful comparison metrics, such as the number of Pareto optimal solutions found by the algorithm, error ratio, generational distance, spacing metric, and diversity metric were applied to validate the efficiency of the proposed HMOIA. Our experimental results indicated that the proposed HMOIA outperforms the multi-objective evolutionary algorithms and improves the quality of the obtained solutions, especially for large-sized problems.

div.p: The authors would like to thank our colleagues as well as the anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments and suggestions, which greatly improved the presentation of this paper. The authors would like to also acknowledge Craig Wilson for improving the readability of this paper.
